title: Semantic Web @ BBN
segmentation: OK, thank you.
Good morning.
I'm going to talk about semantic Web work at BBN with some additional commentary as well on semantic web R&D in the.
States I'm going to start out with a little bit of historical context talk mostly about our current efforts, and also give you a glimpse of some other of.
Our vision, looking forward.
BBN is a company that performs contract research and development in a number of technical areas.
We have about a staff about 700.
Our headquarters is in Cambridge, MA near Boston.
We have about 100 people in the Washington DC area where much most of our semantic web work is based and an additional people including me in other.
Outside the United States.
We basically started as an early MIT spinoff working in the area of architectural acoustics.
Our staff began to kind of expand their interests into experimental psychology, time showing an artificial intelligence.
We're probably best known for our work on the early Arpanet, an Internet with Sri ISI and other organizations.
When I started BBN in 1984, one of the places that would usually take visitors.
Once the network Operation Center for the Defense Data Network which was actually running most of the Internet backbone at that point, you know we've continued to work in.
A number of different areas.
This is basically some of the list of some of the areas that we're involved in, and we have currently have about 30 people working on semantic web related projects.
So I met that many of you initially when I was.
The principle investigator for integration and transition.
You know the DARPA Agent Markup language program.
This was started by Jim Hendler, later led by Mary Burke and Mark Greaves.
And that was one of the very early semantic web efforts.
As part of this program, basically, we coordinated the efforts of 25 research teams.
I chaired the what was called the Joint Committee that developed demo plus oil and this world language and participated in some of the.
RW3 working groups we developed a significant number of tools, datasets and applications in the transition roll.
Some of those evolved into applications and larger projects that have continued to this day.
We also maintained the demo.org and similar central.org websites at one point during doing most of the lifetime of the demo program.
If you googled for DARPA, we were the number three hit.
In contrast to a number of other very large driver programs, such as the Grand Challenge, I think we're 12 today.
Even though the site is currently archived at at.
MIT Summer Central continues to exist.
It's an open source software repository based on G Forge.
Mark was the motivating force behind that.
We currently host 145 semantic web projects.
About 850 people registered with commit rights.
Those projects we're currently in the process of upgrading the hardware and software that supports that platform.
So if you're looking for a good home for your software, consider this one.
Or you'll be among friendly, friendly software and other developers.
Let's say I. Demo is really the first and last large US semantic web research program DARPA, by design and are powered by design.

The director has a tremendous amount of influence over what projects are funded and and work gets done, and I think he basically concluded that this technology development in the semantic web was done once all became a W3C recommendation.
I think in actuality that was really closer to the start.
Into the end of the process, but there hasn't been any large scale reinvestment in services, data integration, or other projects yet.

There have been a number of several smaller RND efforts in other US government agencies and several DARPA stealing projects or sampling projects, which are sort of precursors to larger programs that have more directly addressed some of the semantic technology issues.
So as a result, our shift has really focused.
From technology development in R&D to applications using the semantic web, in some cases these are using it fairly explicitly to solve a problem.

In other cases, basically the customer is looking for a solution to the problem doesn't particularly care what technology is being used, although we often consider semantic web technology are very effective tool to use in providing those solutions.
We have also had basically significant.
Increased activity in in the commercial space.
Working with some medical companies and enough.
Groups many of our applications focus on some aspect of data integration.
The type one activities that that mark talk about.
Basically combining information from diverse sets of databases and web services.
Coreference resolution is among incomplete datasets is an important aspect of many of these applications.
So an example here might be looking at.
Say entities extracted from unstructured text, finding 500 references to John Smith and trying to basically figure out essentially the equivalence classes that those represent it.
Probably not all the same.
They're probably not 500 different.
No quarter of the relationships between those.
BBN has a large group that works on natural language processing our group Semantic Web Group has worked with him on several projects, basically to combine structured and unstructured information.
I think there's a lot of promise there.

In general, structured information coming from databases tends to be more authoritative and complete, but unstructured information coming from news feeds and things like that tends to be much more timely, so being able to combine those things often ends up being very effective.
Much of our data integration work has focused on translation between ontologies.
We use the swirl this map of language as a key part of our solutions, and I'll I'll show some examples of that or discuss that more in a couple slides.
Unless they are one of the things that we've developed is to combine the results of a number of our research projects into a toolkit that we call Azio.
And we've have owl inspired names for many of our things.
As you know, is a genus of owl and Parliament, which you'll see in the lower corner.
Here is the proper name for a flock or collection of owls.

So there's several components of azio, but the probably the most prominent one is something that we call Scout, which basically allows us to perform queries over multiple sets of databases, web services and sparkle endpoints as an example of data integration.
So basically the data sources at the bottom here each has its own what we call a data source ontology, which is basically exposing.
Either automatically or manually the underlying data model for that source in as an L entology.
So in the case of relational databases, we have a tool called Auto Mapper that can generate a simple ontology automatically.
This is somewhat similar, quite similar actually to what data are Q we have some more emergent tools for web services, both soap investible that we also that we.
Also years.

So the goal here basically is that the user expresses a query in what we call the domain Ontology, and this is a vocabulary that would be specific, typically to a given community of interest and we map between the individual data sources and the domain ontology using swirl rules and snuggle.
I didn't actually pick the name, it does, it is not related to else as far as I know.
Is a tool that we basically Aswirl editor that is really focused on Tele Ontology translation.
Basically graphical user interface where people can grab classes and properties from one ontology from another ontology and essentially graphically layout of rule as a mapping between them.
So the semantic query decomposition component of Azure which is really sort of the core brains if you will.
Takes a sparkle query.
Written in the Domain Ontology decomposes it into the relevant queries using the data source ontologies among the different data sources, coordinates the execution and translates the results.
Results coming back the this part is sort of continuing work in progress.
We've sort of a simple applications were basically being able to do joins across multiple data sources that work.
That was fairly easy to do, and.
And quite effective as we begin to really query across data sources that have multiple sets of overlapping data, say instances about information about people.
For example, you know identifying the corresponding people between those things and joining those results and basically doing effective query.
Processing across the datasets can remain some of the challenge.
Essentially all of the classic distributed systems problems are still here, although we feel like we've made some some good progress on that one comment.
The separation of data sources, ontologies and domain ontologies thank his work very well.
One of the things in particular is that we can easily reuse those data sources, basically across different applications by just using.
A different our domain ontology for the other community of interest.
In terms.
Have open source tools.

I touched already on Snagless Warleader that's available in some webcentral folks who want to download it can at last year, so my technology conference I gave a more detailed talk on use of swirl for ontology translation and also comparing it to some of the alternatives.

And folks that are looking for a good representation for expressing the translations might want to take a look at that that talk kind of started when I realize that a lot of folks were still really looking for a solution.
In that space, Parliament is a memory mapped embedded triple store that we originally developed in 2001.
At that point it was called demo DB.
I talked about some more in a talk at the scalable Semantic Web knowledge based Systems Workshop on Sunday and we're planning to soon release an open source version of that on some Web Central.
So it's a little different implementation technique.
And some of the other triple stores are out there.
We've had good results scaling up to, you know, the billion triple range.
And as I said, this is more focused on an embedded system that basically can be layered beneath other tools that folks are already using.
We use it with Sesame and Jena and other tools.
I'd say we've also got quite a bit of work in geospatial semantics.
This grew out of a geospatial semantic web R&D effort at the US National Geospatial Intelligence Agency.
This involved quite a bit of work with geospatial ontologies, including a survey of existing ontologies and relevant data models that there's a link to hear.
Some work that one of my colleagues, Dave Colas, has reported on here.
On adding geospatial indexing and temporal indexing as well to knowledge basis, and we have another ongoing project that's dealing with semantic annotation of Geo registered imagery.
Basically, moving from primarily text based annotations.
An analysis of these images to really using deep semantic structure that can be queried directly.
There are a number of groups that are beginning to work in geospatial semantics in the US, although it's certainly open to other participants as well.
We have what we call the spatial ontology community of practice.
There's the Terra Cognita Workshop series that was held in 2006 and again on Sunday, and there's also a group called USGIF that.
We've been active in.
Going forward, we view this semantic web as a significant growing business area for us.

My boss has sort of coined the term digital white water coming from white water rafting and Rapids and rocks and canoes and things like that as basically sort of a way of addressing the challenge of the information deluge that most people are facing.
Some of the area, you know, the in some sense it's only getting worse with the increasing amount of video content.
You know, we haven't quite figured out how to properly annotate pictures, and now we're getting you know, streaming video video coming at us very quickly.
We're also interested really in moving beyond the relatively static.
All this, you know, sometimes dynamic as well.
Content of web servers to really streaming content and feel like there's a lot of potential in that area.
Meanwhile, we're hoping for a resurgence in semantic web RND.
Regardless of who wins, the US election next week and and takes office in January.
I.
Here's a few more links as well and I'll take any questions.
Questions.

So coming back to something that was talked about in the first talk about trying to move from knowledge engineers to domain experts in these platforms that you're building that do data integration is your model.
That sort of knowledge engineer gets involved in bringing things together.
Or are you trying to build tools that let the domain experts do the data integration themselves?
Mostly, we're still involving involving involving knowledge engineers at this point.
Yeah, I think it certainly would be nice to move in that path, but.
Honestly, most our current work is still the other, more traditional model.
Yes, thanks.
Coming back to a conversation we had yesterday together.
This is about how.
Pizza with your comments about the state of the argument holds in mapping tools where they automatically try to discover that it's OK, yeah?
You can or cannot already use them, right?
OK, that's a good question.
So for our struggle tool as a tool really for helping users to manually define mappings between between ontologies.
One of the things that we would like to do as a next step is to integrate probably the Envia Alignment API is a way of incorporating some of the automated tools in that process.
I haven't followed the recent work there as closely as I probably should have, but.
My feeling is that while those can provide a start, you know that for a user basically to refine and clean up that most of the mappings at this point are still manually manually developed.

So I think it's a promising area of research, but the other thing that's perhaps interesting about our approach that we use, and I think I think many other people do, you do this in some other form with having a domain analogy is that the domain ontology really only needs to cover the aspects of the data source.
Objects that are relevant to that community.

So in many cases, basically there's a mapping from a large number of concepts in the data source ontologies to much smaller number in the main ontology, and that limits the workload that's required for the mappings to some extent.
Mike so I've heard a lot about Asseo.
It's always been kind of vague to me.
What it does?
OK, so, So what does it do?
You think better than anybody else.
Why it does?
Basically is distributed query over multiple semantic web data sources.
I think there's a lot of people who are working toward that.
I'm not aware of anybody who does a better job of it than we do at this point, although an anxious for us to do a better job as well.
Thank you.
